questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding Vulval Intraepithelial Neoplasia (VIN)?

options.A: It is primarily associated with bacterial infection.
options.C: HPV infection is not associated with VIN.
options.D: >50% of cases progress into vulvar cancer.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Smoking is an etiological factor. Explanation: Vulval Intraepithelial Neoplasia (VIN): Etiology HPV infection (HPV DNA found in 80% VIN lesions) (Option C) → Most common serotype - HPV 16 Other STDs - HSV, HIV Cigarette smoking (Option B) Immunosuppression Lichen sclerosus or other chronic dermatological conditions Classification Vulvar LSIL: Self-limited, not precancerous Vulvar HSIL (formerly called Usual VIN): Multicentric and multifocal disease Differentiated VIN: Precursor to most vulvar SCC Clinical features The majority of patients are asymptomatic Non-specific symptoms like pruritus, burning and pain are seen in some patients. HSIL= high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion; LSIL= low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion Incorrect options: Option A: VIN is more closely related to viral infections, particularly human papillomavirus (HPV), rather than bacterial infections. Option D: Majority of VIN patients recover spontaneously. Only 10% of patients progress into vulvar carcinoma. Reference: William’s Textbook of gynaecology, 4th edition, pages 643, 644, 645

questions.question: A 68 Y/o woman presents with complaints of persistent vulvar itching and a lump in the vulvar area. On examination, a lesion is noted on the labia majora. A biopsy of the lesion confirms vulvar squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following is not a risk factor for vulvar carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B)Vulvar hamartoma Explanation: Vulvar Hamartoma: A vulvar hamartoma is a benign tumor-like growth that occurs on the vulva, which is the external part of the female genitalia. Hamartomas are made up of an abnormal mixture of tissue types that are normally found in the area but are disorganized and overgrown. Risk factors: HPV infection:(Option C) The most significant risk factor for vulvar carcinoma is infection with Human papilloma Virus (HPV), particularly high-risk serotypes such as HPV 16 & 18 (option C). 50-75% of invasive vulvar cancers are associated with high risk HPV infections. Smoking:(Option A) Women who smoke and have a history of HPV infection have a 35 fold greater risk of developing vulvar cancer. Vulvar Intraepithelial Neoplasia: VIN is a precancerous condition, of which 10% of cases progress into Vulvar cancer Chronic Immunosuppression: HIV infection and organ transplantation. Chronic dermatological conditions: (Option D) Lichen sclerosus:Differentiated VIN is a precursor to keratinizing squamous cellcarcinoma and is strongly associated with lichen sclerosus. Lichen sclerosus is a skin condition that causes itchy white patches on the genitals or other parts of the body

questions.question: Which of the following subtypes of squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva is most commonly associated with lichen sclerosus and typically occurs in postmenopausal women?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Keratinizing carcinoma Explanation: Vulvar carcinoma: Vulvar carcinoma constitutes 6% of all gynecological tumors. The average age of diagnosis is 65 years.(50-70 years) The most common subtype of Vulvar carcinoma is squamous cell carcinoma followed by melanoma. Subtypes of Vulvar squamous cell carcinoma (vSCC): Warty/Basaloid vSCC Keratinizing vSCC Age group Seen in younger women Seen in older women Risk factors HPV infection (16 & 18), Smoking, Immunosuppression Chronic dermatological conditions such as lichen sclerosus Association with Usual Vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (HSIL) P53 mutant differentiated vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia Lesion Multifocal Unifocal Prognosis Better Worse Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7446361/#B7 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK5 67798/#:~:text=Vulvar%20SCC%20can%20be%20categorized,patients%20and%20is%20HPV%2Dindependent. ht tps://www.researchgate.net/figure/Characteristics-of-two-types-of-squamous-cell-carcinoma-of-the-vulva-Characte ristics_tbl1_49711694

questions.question: A 68 y/o female presents with a vulvar lesion on her labia majora. It measures 0.8 cm and has been present for several weeks. She reports persistent itching. What is the MOST appropriate investigation for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Excisional biopsy Explanation: In the above scenario, in a post-menopausal woman, a vulvar lesion on the labia with persistent itching is most likely to be Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the vulva which is confirmed after biopsy. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the vulva Site Labia majora is the most common (60%). Clitoris 2nd most common (15%). Most common in 50-70 years age group Presentation Exophytic (outward-growing) and ulcerative (open sore) growth. Symptom Pruritus (most common): Often associated with an itch-scratch cycle. Cancer cachexia (weight loss and muscle wasting). Cancer pain. Spread Primarily spreads through the lymphatic system. Vulvar lymphatics cross over at the midline, especially within 2 cm of the midline. The inguinofemoral lymph nodes are the most commonly involved group. Lymph node involvement significantly affects prognosis. Investigations Excisional biopsy (IOC): For lesions < 1 cm in size. Complete lesion removal and histological assessment, including invasion presence and depth. (Option C) Incisional biopsy: For lesions ≥ 1 cm in size. (Option D) Wedge biopsy. Keyes punch biopsy. Sentinel lymph node biopsy: Assess lymph node involvement, particularly the inguinofemoral nodes. Vulvoscopy (Option A) is Limited to visual assessment; does not provide a definitive diagnosis. Colposcopy (Option B) A valuable tool for visualizing and identifying suspicious areas for biopsy. However, it is not a diagnostic procedure on its own. Reference: William’s Textbook of Gynecology, 4th edition, pages 677,678.

questions.question: Which of the following is a contraindication of sentinel lymph node biopsy in vulvar cancer?

options.A: Tumor is located on the labia majora.
options.B: Tumor is smaller than 4 cm in diameter.
options.C: Tumor invades > 1 mm into the stroma.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Clinically suspicious groin lymph nodes. Explanation: Sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB): The sentinel lymph node is the first to receive lymphatic drainage from a tumour. Sentinel lymph node biopsy involves inguinofemoral nodes ( Superficial inguinal lymph nodes) using Technetium 99 or isosulphan blue dye. Positive sentinel node: Radical lymphadenectomy. Negative sentinel node: Only vulvectomy needed. B/l inguinofemoral nodes are dissected for SLNB (if mass lies within 2 cm of the midline) Prognostic significance: Without groin node metastasis: >90% 5-year survival rate. With groin node metastasis: 50% 5-year survival rate. Indications of SLNB: Unifocal tumors confined to the vulva. Tumors <4 cm in diameter. Stromal invasion >1 mm. (Option C) Clinically and radiologically negative groin nodes. Contraindication of SLNB: SLNB is not performed if there is clinical suspicion of groin node metastasis because the goal of SLNB is to determine if the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes. If there is already clinical suspicion of metastasis, a more extensive inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy is typically performed. Options A and B: The decision to perform SLNB is based on factors such as tumor location, size, invasion depth, and clinical suspicion of lymph node metastasis. Reference: William’s Textbook of Gynecology, 4th edition, pages 683, 684 https://obgyn.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ijgo.13881

questions.question: A 68-year-old woman presents with a 3 cm ulcerated lesion on the left labia majora. Biopsy confirms invasive squamous cell carcinoma. Physical examination reveals two palpable, mobile lymph nodes in the left groin, each measuring approximately 1 mm in diameter. What is the most likely FIGO stage of her vulvar cancer?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Stage IIIA Explanation: The patient in this scenario has a T2 tumor (>2 cm in size) with the involvement of two inguinal lymph nodes (N2a). According to the FIGO staging for invasive vulvar cancer, this clinical presentation corresponds to Stage IIIA. Staging of Invasive Vulvar Cancer Stage 1 Limited to vulva. 1a Tumor ≤ 2 cm, stromal invasion ≤ 1 mm, no nodal metastasis (Option A) 1b Tumor > 2 cm, stromal invasion > 1 mm with negative nodes (Option B) Stage II Tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (1/3 lower urethra, 1/3 lower vagina, anus) with negative nodes Stage III Tumor of any size with extension to upper I vagina, upper I urethra, bladder, or rectum. IIIa Regional LN ≤ 5 mm (Option C) IIIb Regional LN > 5 mm IIIc Regional LN with extracapsular spread. Stage IV IVa Tumor invades any of the following: upper urethral and/or vaginal mucosa, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa, or fixed to the pelvic bone, or Fixed or ulcerated inguinofemoral lymph nodes. (Option D) IVb Distant metastasis, including pelvic lymph nodes Regional LN refers to inguinal and femoral lymph nodes. Reference: William’s Textbook of Gynaecology, 4th edition, pages 679, 680, 681

questions.question: A 68y/o woman presents with a 3 cm vulvar lesion. Biopsy confirms invasive squamous cell carcinoma with a depth of invasion of 1.5 mm. Her inguinal lymph nodes are clinically negative. What is the most appropriate treatment?

options.A: Radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy
options.B: Wide local excision with sentinel lymph node biopsy
options.D: Simple vulvectomy without lymph node assessment

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy Treatment of Tumor Stages of Vulval Cancer Stage 1 1a (Option B) Wide local excision with a 1-cm margin is performed for the probable cure. 1b Radical resection of the primary tumor and inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy (LAD). Central lesion: B/L LAD Lateral lesion (> 2 cm from midline): U/L LAD. Stage II Radical vulvectomy + B/L LAD Positive LN involvement in HPE - Must do pelvic LAD or pelvic LN radiotherapy. Stage III Radical partial or total vulvectomy and either SLNB or inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy. Postoperative adjuvant radiation (4000-5000 Rads over 5 weeks) directed to both the groins and the pelvis. Stage IV Treated with chemotherapy or radiotherapy Chemotherapy: 5-FU, mitomycin C Other agents used are Methotrexate, bleomycin, and trastuzumab. Option C: Chemoradiation therapy alone is typically reserved for patients who cannot undergo surgery due to medical comorbidities or in cases where the tumor is not resectable and incase of distant metastasis Option D: Simple vulvectomy alone does not adequately address the potential risk of lymph node metastasis. SLNB is important to rule out microscopic lymph node involvement, even in the early stages. Reference: William’s Textbook of Gynaecology, 4th edition, pages 684,685, 686, 687

questions.question: A 68 Y/o female presents with complaints of persistent vulvar itching and a noticeable lump in the vulvar region. A biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva. the growth is limited to the vulva with no clinically palpable groin nodes. Imaging studies reveal no distant metastasis. Which of the following statements most accurately reflects the 5-year survival rate for this patient?

options.A: The 5-year survival rate is less than 30%
options.B: The 5-year survival rate is between 30% and 50%
options.C: The 5-year survival rate is between 50% and 70%
options.D: The 5-year survival rate is between 70% and 90%

questions.explanation: scenario, the patient is likely to have stage I vulvar squamous cell carcinoma. Prognosis of vulvar cancer: FIGO staging 5-year survival rate Stage I & II (no lymphatic involvement) 70-90% (Option D) Stage III (inguinofemoral lymph node involvement) 30-50% (Option B) Stage IV (tumor with regional spread) ≤ 30% (Option A) Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynecology, 17th edition, page no: 477 https://www.cancercenter.com/cancer-types/ vulvar-cancer/stages#:~:text=Localized%3A%20The%20cancer%20has%20not,cancer%20is%20about%2053%20 percent.

questions.question: A 20-year-old woman with a history of in utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES) presents with a mass in the upper third of the anterior vaginal wall. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.A: Squamous cell carcinoma of the vagina
options.B: Clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina Explanation: The patient's age and history of DES exposure make this the most likely diagnosis. Clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina is closely linked to in-utero DES exposure. Most DES-exposed patients with vaginal cancer were born between 1951 and 1956 when the drug was most frequently prescribed. Vaginal Carcinoma Etiology Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection; HPV 16 is most common. In utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES) Chronic vaginal irritation or inflammation. Previous cervical or vulvar cancer. Vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia General population DES-exposed women during pregnancy Most Common Site Upper third of the vagina, particularly the posterior wall. Upper third of the vagina, particularly the anterior wall. Most Common Histological Type Squamous cell carcinoma (Option A) Clear cell adenocarcinoma (Option B) Clinical Features Painless vaginal bleeding and abnormal discharge (M/C symptom) Post-coital bleeding Vaginal mass or ulcer Pelvic pain Dyspareunia (pain during intercourse) Option C: Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma of the vagina is the most common malignancy of the vagina in infants and children, typically occurring in girls younger than 5 years old. Option D: Leiomyosarcoma of the vagina is the most common type of vaginal sarcoma in adults, usually affecting women older than 40 years old. Reference: William’s Textbook of Gynecology, 4th edition, page 695.

questions.question: A 25 y/o woman presents with a history of abnormal Pap test results. Colposcopy reveals a well-defined, white lesion in the upper third of the vagina. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis of vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia (VAIN). What is the most likely stage of this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Stage 0 Explanation: This patient's biopsy confirms VAIN, which is considered a pre-invasive lesion. Pre-invasive lesions are classified as Stage 0, as they haven't invaded the surrounding tissue. Staging of Vaginal Carcinoma Stage Characteristics 0 Carcinoma in situ, Intraepithelial neoplasia (VAIN) (Option A) I Cancer is limited to the vaginal wall. II Cancer has spread to the subvaginal tissue but not to the pelvic wall. (Option B) III Cancer has spread to the pelvic wall and/or regional lymph nodes. (Option C) IVA Tumor invades bladder and/or rectal mucosa and/or direct extension beyond the true pelvis. (Option D) IVB Spread to distant organs. Management of VAIN: Observation : For low-grade lesions, especially in younger or postmenopausal women without symptoms. Involves repeat colposcopy and biopsy. Wide Excision: Involves surgically removing the VAIN lesion along with a margin of healthy tissue. This serves as a definitive treatment and is often the preferred approach for high-grade VAIN. Laser ablation : For localized high-grade lesions. Topical Treatments: Application of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) cream, Imiquimod (5%), Dinitrochlorobenzene for high-grade lesions. Follow-up : Regular surveillance with Pap smears and colposcopy to monitor for progression or recurrence. Reference: William’s Textbook of Gynaecology, 4th Edition, pages 691, 692

questions.question: A 60 y/o woman presents with intermittent vaginal bleeding for the past 3 months with a past history of hysterectomy. Pelvic examination reveals a 1.5 cm mass confined to the lower third of the vagina. Biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Radical vaginectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy Explanation: The patient's presentation aligns with Stage I vaginal cancer, characterized by the carcinoma being limited to the vaginal wall. For Stage I disease, surgery is the preferred treatment if negative surgical margins can be achieved. Management of vaginal carcinoma Stage Location Treatment Stage I Upper 1/3rd Surgery : Partial vulvectomy, radical hysterectomy (if uterus present), and B/L pelvic lymphadenectomy. Middle 1/3rd Surgery : Radical vulvectomy + B/L inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy or Radiation : External beam, brachytherapy, or combination Lower 1/3rd Stage II Any Radiation alone (Preferred): Combination of External beam & brachytherapy Stage III & IVA Any Radiation : Usually the primary treatment, often combined with chemotherapy (especially cisplatin) Stage IVA: Pelvic exenteration &/or Radiation Stage IVB Any Chemotherapy : Considered for metastatic disease Supportive Care : Palliative care. Ovary transposition is performed in young women before pelvic radiotherapy to prevent premature ovarian insufficiency. (Option B) Brachytherapy alone : Although brachytherapy can be used to treat some selected small Stage I vaginal cancer lesions, it is typically not sufficient as a standalone treatment for most patients. (Option C) Wide local excision : Wide local excision is generally considered for earlier-stage vaginal lesions or pre-invasive disease. (Option D) External beam radiation and chemotherapy: This combination is typically considered for more advanced vaginal cancer stages (Stage II and beyond). Reference: William’s Textbook of Gyneacology ,4th edition, page no: 692, 693, 694

questions.question: A 62-year-old woman has been diagnosed with SCC arising from the Bartholin gland following a biopsy after she presented with complaints of unilateral swelling in the vulvar area. Which of the following is an indication for bartholin gland biopsy?

options.C: Solid mass arising from Bartholin gland

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All of the above Explanation: Women over 40 years of age who have recurrent Bartholin cysts/abscesses or solid masses should have a biopsy performed. Bartholin gland carcinoma Maybe adenocarcinomas, SCC, or transitional cell carcinoma Clinical features Painless vulval mass Perineal pain Dyspareunia Spreads to ischiorectal fossa and pelvic nodes Investigations MRI Bartholin biopsy: Indications include, Woman over 40 years Recurrent cyst/abscess All solid masses Treatment Radical vulvectomy + Ipsilateral/bilateral groin dissection Pre/post-operative chemoradiation Reference: 1. William’s gynecology, 4th edition, page 688 2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9906066/

questions.question: A 66 Y/o woman presents with complaints of persistent pain, and a visible lump in her vulvar region. On examination, the gynecologist notes a raised lesion on the labia majora. A biopsy is performed, and the results are indicative of malignancy. Which of the following is the most common subtype of vulvar cancer?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Squamous cell carcinoma Explanation: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common subtype of vulvar carcinoma followed by malignant melanoma. Classification of Vulvar carcinoma: Reference: William’s Textbook of Gynecology, 4th edition, page 677

questions.question: A 72y/o woman presents with a vulvar lesion for the past 6 months. She reports persistent pruritus and occasional bleeding from the lesion. On examination, a 2 cm ulcerated lesion is found on the labia majora. A biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma. Which lymph nodes are MOST commonly involved in the lymphatic drainage and spread of vulvar carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Inguinofemoral lymph nodes Explanation: This patient was diagnosed with Squamous cell carcinoma of vulva. Inguinofemoral lymph nodes are the most common and superficial inguinal node is the Sentinel lymph node drainage for vulva. Lymph node involvement is crucial for prognosis and surgical planning. Lymphatic drainage of the vulva Location of Lesion Primary Drainage Site Notes Lateral Vulva Ipsilateral superficial inguinal lymph nodes. Vulvar lymphatics do not cross the labiocrural folds. Within 2 cm of Midline Either superficial inguinal lymph node group. Lesions in this area may spread to either side. Clitoris and Upper Labia Drain directly to the deep femoral nodes. Entire Vulva (Distal Third of Vagina) Superficial inguinal node group Lymph travels to the deep femoral lymphatics and then through the node of Cloquet to the pelvic lymph nodes (meaning distant metastasis). (Option C) Option A: The para-aortic lymph nodes are primarily involved in the drainage of abdominal organs, such as the kidneys and intestines. Option D: The axillary lymph nodes are responsible for the upper limbs, chest, and breast drainage.

questions.question: A 68 Y/o woman presents with a 6-month history of persistent vulvar itching and burning. She reports noticing a red, velvety rash on her vulva that occasionally oozes. On physical examination, there is an erythematous and eczematous lesion on the vulva. Biopsy of the lesion reveals large cells with abundant cytoplasm in epithelium. Which of the following is most likely the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Paget's disease of the vulva Explanation: The 68 year old postmenopausal woman with red velvety, eczematous lesions on the vulva most likely have paget’s disease of vulva. Paget’s disease of vulva Most common extramammary Paget’s disease, originating from apocrine glands and proliferates into the epithelium. 10-20% of people are associated with invasive Paget’s disease or adenocarcinoma of vulva. Symptoms: Erythematous chronic skin lesions associated with pruritus, burning and pain. Multifocal well-demarcated velvety erythematous plaques, more commonly seen on labia majora. Biopsy of the lesion shows paget’s cells (large cells with abundant cytoplasm) in the epithelium Treatment Non-invasive disease: lesions are resected by wide local excision with 1-2 cm margin. Invasive disease: Radical partial vulvectomy with/without inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy. Option A: Lichen sclerosus is a chronic dermatological condition seen in prepubertal girls and postmenopausal women. Porcelain white plaques are seen in lichen sclerosus. Option C: Vulvar candidiasis is a gynecological infection commonly seen in immunosuppressed or diabetic patients. Curdy white discharge is usually seen. Option D: Bowen’s disease, a precancerous condition that may progress into invasive squamous cell carcinoma, is characterized by tender, erythematous epidermal lesion with induration. Reference: 1. William's Textbook of Gynecology,4th edition, pages 95, 688, 689 2. https://ccij-online.org/storage/files/article/ccij-kssjamier1o-865/ClinCancerInvestigJ_2020_9_5_210_298002.pdf 3.

questions.question: A 62-year-old woman presents with complaints of persistent vulvar itching and a non-healing lesion on her vulva. On PE, a thickened, whitish plaque and ulceration are noted on the labia majora. Histopathology reveals atypical squamous cells confined to the epithelium with marked basal atypia and abnormal keratinisation as shown below. Which of the following is the patient suffering from?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Differentiated VIN Explanation: Classification of Vulval Intraepithelial Neoplasia: Normal vulva Lined by stratified squamous epithelium Vulvar LSIL Seen in younger women (option B) Etiology: HPV effect Flat lesions with condyloma Self limited, not precancerous Histology: Mild atypical cells in the lower third of epithelium Koilocytes in the upper layer Vulval HSIL Formerly called usual VIN (option A&C) Seen in younger women Etiology: HPV infection, STDs, immunosuppression, smoking Multicentric & multifocal disease Precancerous condition Histology: Atypical squamous cells in all layers of epithelium Extensive parakeratosis Koilocytic changes in the upper layer. Differentiated VIN Seen in older, postmenopausal women (option D) Etiology: Lichen sclerosus and other chronic dermatological conditions Unicentric and unifocal disease Precancerous condition Histology: Prominent nucleoli Basal atypia with acanthosis, dyskeratosis Investigations: Lesions are usually sharply demarcated. In usual VIN, lesions appear bulky, resembling condylomata and are multifocal. In differentiated VIN, lesions are unifocal and may be associated with inflammatory dermatitis such as lichen sclerosus. Vulvoscopy: Vulvar epithelial changes are observed after application of acetic acid and the most abnormal appearing areas are biopsied. Treatment: Vulvar LSIL Self-limited condition. Not treated unless symptomatic. Vulvar HSIL and differentiated VIN Precancerous conditions. All lesions should be treated. Treatment options: Wide local excision Laser ablation Topical 5-FU or imiquimod
